title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

The boy gives 12/3 = <<12/3=4>>4 oranges to his brother.
The remainder is 12 - 4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges.
The boy gives his friend 8/4 = <<8/4=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

One-third of 12 is (1/3)*12 = <<(1/3)*12=4>>4 oranges.
The remainder is 12-4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges.
One-fourth of 8 is (1/4)*8 = <<(1/4)*8=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

One-third of 12 oranges is (1/3)*12 = <<(1/3)*12=4>>4 oranges.
The first boy remains with 12 oranges - 4 oranges = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges after giving out some to his brother.
One-fourth of 8 oranges is (1/4)*8 = <<(1/4)*8=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

The boy gives 1/3 * 12 = <<1/3*12=4>>4 oranges to his brother.
The remainder is 12 - 4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges.
He gives 1/4 * 8 = <<1/4*8=2>>2 oranges to his friend. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

The boy gives 12 x 1/3 = <<12*1/3=4>>4 oranges to his brother.
So he has 12 - 4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges left.
Then he gives 8 x 1/4 = <<8*1/4=2>>2 oranges to his friend. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A cook had 300 carrots in a bucket he was using to cook meals for a restaurant. Before lunch, he had used 2/5 of the carrots. By the end of the day, he had chopped and used 3/5 of the remaining carrots. How many carrots were not used that day?
text:
The cook used 2/5 of the 300 carrots, which is (2/5) * 300 = 120 carrots.
So he had 300 - 120 = 180 carrots remaining.
He then used 3/5 of the remaining 180 carrots, which is (3/5) * 180 = 108 carrots.
Therefore, the cook did not use 180 - 108 = 72 carrots that day. Answer: \boxed{72}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Greg has lent his sister Tessa money on several occasions. Greg writes down all of his sister's debts in a notebook, the first time he lent her $40. A week later, Tessa paid him back half of her debt. A few days later she asked him for $10 more. How much does Tessa still owe Greg?

Tessa paid Greg back half of her $40 debt, so she paid him 1/2 * 40 = $<<1/2*40=20>>20.
Her debt was reduced by $20, so she owes Greg $40 - $20 = $<<40-20=20>>20.
When she asked for $10 more, her debt increased to $20 + $10 = $<<20+10=30>>30.
Tessa still owes Greg $<<30=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Greg has lent his sister Tessa money on several occasions. Greg writes down all of his sister's debts in a notebook, the first time he lent her $40. A week later, Tessa paid him back half of her debt. A few days later she asked him for $10 more. How much does Tessa still owe Greg?

Tessa paid Greg back half of the debt, which is 40/2 = $<<40/2=20>>20.
So she owes Greg 40 - 20= $<<40-20=20>>20.
Meaning Tessa owes Greg 20+ 10 = <<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Greg has lent his sister Tessa money on several occasions. Greg writes down all of his sister's debts in a notebook, the first time he lent her $40. A week later, Tessa paid him back half of her debt. A few days later she asked him for $10 more. How much does Tessa still owe Greg?

Tessa paid back half of her debt which was $40 so 40/2 = $<<40/2=20>>20
After Tessa asked him for $10 more her debt was 20 + 10 = $<<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Greg has lent his sister Tessa money on several occasions. Greg writes down all of his sister's debts in a notebook, the first time he lent her $40. A week later, Tessa paid him back half of her debt. A few days later she asked him for $10 more. How much does Tessa still owe Greg?

When Greg lent her $40, Tessa paid him back half of her debt, which is 1/2 * $40 = $<<1/2*40=20>>20.
So far, Tessa still owes Greg $40 - $20 = $<<40-20=20>>20.
When Tessa asked Greg for $10 more, Tessa now owes Greg a total of $20 + $10 = $<<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Greg has lent his sister Tessa money on several occasions. Greg writes down all of his sister's debts in a notebook, the first time he lent her $40. A week later, Tessa paid him back half of her debt. A few days later she asked him for $10 more. How much does Tessa still owe Greg?

The first time, Greg lent Tessa $40.
A week later, Tessa paid back half of her debt, which is $40 / 2 = $<<40/2=20>>20.
So the debt balance is $40 - $20 = $<<40-20=20>>20.
After that, Tessa asked for $10 more, so the total debt is $20 + $10 = $<<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Nancy's ex owes her child support. He's supposed to pay 30% of his income each year. For 3 years, he made $30,000/year, then he got a 20% raise for the next four years. If he's only ever paid $1,200, how much does he owe her?
text:
In the first 3 years, he made $30,000/year, so he owes Nancy 30% * $30,000 * 3 = $<<0.30*30000*3=27000>>27,000.
For the next 4 years, he made a 20% raise, so he made $30,000 * 1.2 = $<<30000*1.2=36000>>36,000/year.
In those 4 years, he was supposed to pay 30% * $36,000 * 4 = $<<0.30*36000*4=43200>>43,200.
Therefore, Nancy's ex still owes her $27,000 + $43,200 - $1,200 = $<<27000+43200-1200=69000>>69,000. Answer: \boxed{69,000}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Albert wants a paintbrush that costs $1.50, a set of paints that costs $4.35, and a wooden easel that costs $12.65. Albert already has $6.50. How much more money does Albert need?

The total cost of all the items is $1.50 + $4.35 + $12.65 = $<<1.5+4.35+12.65=18.50>>18.50
Albert needs $18.50 − $6.50 = $<<18.50-6.50=12>>12 more. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Dexter and Jay are using a gallon of white paint to paint the walls. Dexter used 3/8 of the gallon of paint while Jay used 5/8 of a gallon of paint. If a gallon is equal to 4 liters, how many liters of paint were left from Dexter and Jay combined?

Dexter used 4 x 3/8 = <<4*3/8=1.5>>1.5 liters of paint.
Jay used 4 x 5/8 = <<4*5/8=2.5>>2.5 liters of paint.
Therefore, there were 1.5 + 2.5 = <<1.5+2.5=4>>4 liters of paint left from them both. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Albert wants a paintbrush that costs $1.50, a set of paints that costs $4.35, and a wooden easel that costs $12.65. Albert already has $6.50. How much more money does Albert need?

Albert needs $1.50 + $4.35 + $12.65 - $6.50 = $<<1.50+4.35+12.65-6.50=12>>12 more. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Keaton climbed a 30 feet ladder twenty times while working at the construction site. Reece, also working at the same site, climbed a ladder 4 feet shorter than Keaton's ladder 15 times. What's the total length of the ladders that both workers climbed in inches?

If Keaton climbed a ladder twenty times, climbing 30 feet each time, his total is 20*30 = <<20*30=600>>600 feet.
Reece, climbing a 4 feet shorter ladder fifteen times, climbs a total of 15*(30-4) = <<15*(30-4)=390>>390 feet.
Converting Keaton's Climb to inches gives 600*12 = <<600*12=7200>>7200 inches
Similarly, Reece's climb in inches is 390*12 = <<390*12=4680>>4680 inches.
Together, Reece and Keaton climbed 4680+7200 = <<4680+7200=11880>>11880 inches. Answer: \boxed{11880}.


Question: Jill is painting her 20 toenails and fingernails. She paints 6 of her nails purple, 8 of them blue, and the rest striped. What is the difference in percentage points between the percentage of nails painted blue and the percentage painted striped?

The total number of striped nails is 20 - 6 - 8 = <<20-6-8=6>>6.
The percentage of striped nails is 6/20 * 100% = 30%.
The difference between the percentage of blue nails and striped nails is 8/20 * 100% - 30% = 40% - 30% = <<8/20*100%-30%=10>>10%. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: Tommy has a flag that is 5 feet wide and 4 feet tall. He wants to paint it with a new design. He knows from experience that he needs to paint both sides. Paint costs $2 a quart and a quart is good for 4 square feet. How much does he spend on paint?
text:
The area of one side of the flag is 5 feet * 4 feet = <<5*4=20>>20 square feet.
Since he needs to paint both sides, the total area is 20 square feet * 2 = <<20*2=40>>40 square feet.
He needs 40 square feet / 4 square feet per quart = <<40/4=10>>10 quarts.
He spends 10 quarts * $2 per quart = $<<10*2=20>>20 on paint. Answer: \boxed{20}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby has 5 balls * 80 rotations per ball = <<5*80=400>>400 rotations.
Toby's friend has 4 apples * 101 rotations per apple = <<4*101=404>>404 rotations.
The winner has 404 >=  400 meaning the maximum is 404 rotations. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby rotates 400 baseballs because 5 x 80 = <<5*80=400>>400
His friend rotates 404 apples because 4 x 101 = <<4*101=404>>404
His friend wins because 404 > 400.
The winner rotates 404 objects. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby makes 400 rotations because 5 x 80 = <<5*80=400>>400
His friend does 404 rotations because 4 x 101 = <<4*101=404>>404
The winner made 404 rotations because 404 > 400
The winner made 404 rotations because 404 > 400. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Emily has 7 times as many oranges as Sandra. Sandra has 3 times as many oranges as Betty. If Betty has 12 oranges, how many oranges does Emily have?

Sandra has 3 * 12 oranges = <<3*12=36>>36 oranges.
Emily has 7 * 36 oranges = <<7*36=252>>252 oranges. Answer: \boxed{252}.


Question: Emily has 7 times as many oranges as Sandra. Sandra has 3 times as many oranges as Betty. If Betty has 12 oranges, how many oranges does Emily have?

Sandra has 3 * 12 oranges = <<3*12=36>>36 oranges.
Emily has 36 oranges * 7 = <<36*7=252>>252 oranges. Answer: \boxed{252}.


Question: Katrina has 120 cookies to sell at her bakery. She plans to take home any cookies she doesn’t sell by the end of the day. In the morning, she sells 3 dozen cookies. During the lunch rush, she sells 57 cookies. In the afternoon, she sells 16 more cookies. How many cookies does she have left to take home?
text:
Katrina sells 3 dozen cookies in the morning, which is equal to 3 x 12 = 36 cookies.
She sells 57 cookies during the lunch rush.
In the afternoon, she sells an additional 16 cookies.
Therefore, she sold a total of 36 + 57 + 16 = 109 cookies.
She started with 120 cookies, so she has 120 - 109 = 11 cookies left to take home. Answer: \boxed{11}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian has a total of 80 * 10 = <<80*10=800>>800 equal pieces of oranges.
Thus she had 800 / 4 = <<800/4=200>>200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby has 5 balls * 80 rotations per ball = <<5*80=400>>400 rotations.
Toby's friend has 4 apples * 101 rotations per apple = <<4*101=404>>404 rotations.
The winner has 404 >=  400 meaning the maximum is 404 rotations. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby rotates 400 baseballs because 5 x 80 = <<5*80=400>>400
His friend rotates 404 apples because 4 x 101 = <<4*101=404>>404
His friend wins because 404 > 400.
The winner rotates 404 objects. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian had a total of 80 x 10 = <<80*10=800>>800 pieces.
Therefore there were 800 / 4 = <<800/4=200>>200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Jason is tired of the neighborhood animals raiding his trash. He pepper-sprays some raccoons and 6 times as many squirrels. If he pepper-sprays 84 animals total, how many raccoons does he pepper-spray?

Let R be the number of raccoons Jason pepper-sprays and S be the number of squirrels. We know that R + S = 84 and S = 6R.
Substituting the second equation into the first equation, we get R + 6R = 84
Combining like terms, we get 7R = 84
Dividing both sides by 7, we get R = 12. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Avery puts 4 shirts in the donation box.  He adds twice as many pants as shirts in the box.  He throws in half as many shorts as pants in the box. In total, how many pieces of clothes is Avery donating?
text:
Let S be the number of shirts, P be the number of pants, and R be the number of shorts. We know that P = 2S and R = (1/2)P. 
We also know that S + P + R = the total number of clothes.
Substituting the values of P and R into the equation, we get S + 2S + (1/2)(2S) = the total number of clothes.
Simplifying, we get 4S = the total number of clothes.
Therefore, the total number of clothes Avery is donating is 4 * 4 = 16. Answer: \boxed{16}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Anderson makes mud masks for spa treatments. In every batch of mud that he mixes, he adds three sprigs of mint, and he adds two green tea leaves for every sprig of mint. He had to switch to a different kind of mud, which makes the other ingredients he adds half as effective. How many green tea leaves should Anderson add to a new batch of mud to get the same efficacy as before?

In every batch, Anderson adds 3 sprigs of mint.
He adds 2 green tea leaves for every sprig of mint, so he adds 3 * 2 = <<3*2=6>>6 green tea leaves in every batch.
The new mud makes the other ingredients half as effective, so Anderson should add 6 * 2 = <<6*2=12>>12 green tea leaves to get the same efficacy as before. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Mickey's number is greater than Jayden's number by exactly 20. If Jayden's number is 40 less than Coraline's number, and Coraline's number is 80, calculate the total of the numbers they have.

If Coraline's number is 80, Jayden's number is 80-40 = <<80-40=40>>40
Mickey's number is 40+20 = <<40+20=60>>60 which is 20 greater than Jayden's number.
Jayden's number is 60-20 = <<60-20=40>>40
Together, the three have 60+40+80 = <<60+40+80=180>>180. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

The boy gives 12/3 = <<12/3=4>>4 oranges to his brother.
The remainder is 12 - 4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges.
The boy gives his friend 8/4 = <<8/4=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: Mickey's number is greater than Jayden's number by exactly 20. If Jayden's number is 40 less than Coraline's number, and Coraline's number is 80, calculate the total of the numbers they have.

If Coraline's number is 80, then Jayden's number is 80-40 = <<80-40=40>>40.
Mickey's number is 20+40 = <<20+40=60>>60
The total of the numbers they have is 80+40+60 = <<80+40+60=180>>180. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: Mickey's number is greater than Jayden's number by exactly 20. If Jayden's number is 40 less than Coraline's number, and Coraline's number is 80, calculate the total of the numbers they have.

Jayden's number is 80-40 = <<80-40=40>>40.
Mickey's number is 40+20 = <<40+20=60>>60.
The total of the numbers the three have is 40+60+80 = <<40+60+80=180>>180. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: Ethan makes beeswax candles.  For each candle, he uses 8 ounces of beeswax and 1 ounce of coconut oil.  If he makes three less than 10 candles, what will be the combined weight of the candles in ounces?
text:
If Ethan makes 10 candles, he will use 10 * 8 = <<10*8=80>>80 ounces of beeswax.
He will also use 10 * 1 = <<10*1=10>>10 ounces of coconut oil.
If he makes three less than 10 candles, he will make 10 - 3 = <<10-3=7>>7 candles.
The combined weight of the candles will be 7 * (8 + 1) = 7 * 9 = <<7*9=63>>63 ounces. Answer: \boxed{63}.
